title: 105_s708
content: The Act is titled the "Deadly Driver Reduction and Matthew P. Hammell Memorial Act" and includes a minimum penalty for individuals driving under the influence of alcohol. The "Deadly Driver Reduction and Matthew P. Hammell Memorial Act" introduces a national minimum penalty for individuals operating a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol. It includes provisions for withholding federal funds from states that do not comply with the requirements. The "Deadly Driver Reduction and Matthew P. Hammell Memorial Act" establishes a national minimum penalty for driving under the influence of alcohol, requiring states to enforce laws with specific penalties for offenders. The "Deadly Driver Reduction and Matthew P. Hammell Memorial Act" mandates revocation of driver's license for at least 1 year for operating a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol, with permanent revocation for third or subsequent offenses. No exceptions or conditions apply to the revocation. Funds withheld under subsection (a) have specific availability periods based on the date of withholding. Funds withheld on or before September 30, 2002, remain available for three fiscal years after the year they were authorized. However, funds withheld after September 30, 2002, are not available for apportionment to the State. The Secretary will apportion withheld funds to the State if the State meets the requirements within a specific timeframe. The apportioned funds will remain available for expenditure until the end of the third fiscal year following the year of apportionment. Unobligated sums at the end of this period will be forfeited.
